newsitem.title: USA: Adobe Systems shares rise on better-than-expected profits.
newsitem.headline: Adobe Systems shares rise on better-than-expected profits.

text.p: Adobe Systems Inc. shares jumped 11 percent Wednesday after the software company reported better-than-expected first-quarter earnings on strong sales of its graphics editing computer programmes.
Shares of Adobe, the nation's third-biggest personal computer software company, rose $3.75 to $38.625 on Nasdaq trading of almost 7.1 million shares.

After the market closed Tuesday, Adobe said profits from operations for the quarter ended Feb. 28 rose 35 percent to $45.4 million, or 61 cents a share. Wall Street had expected Adobe to earn 51 cents a share, according to a recent survey by Zacks Investment Research.
First-quarter revenue rose 17 percent to $226.5 million, the San Jose, Calif.-based company said.

Adobe writes computer programmes that help graphic artists design publications and make illustrations. Much of the strong sales during the quarter came from a new version of PageMaker, a page layout programme, the company said.
The company also has "good fundamental demand" for PhotoShop, a digital photo-enhancement programme, said Mike Wallace, an analyst at UBS Securities in New York.

"They're in the middle of upgrading all of their major products," Wallace said. Aggressive cost control also helped Adobe improve its gross margins -- a measure of profit on every dollar of product sold -- by three points to 85 percent, he said.

Adobe also runs a venture capital operation that invests in Silicon Valley startups. Adobe said Tuesday that it plans to pay a dividend based on the profit it makes from investments in other companies.
Based on the better-than-expected earnings, at least four Wall Street analysts raised their rating on Adobe's stock or boosted their earnings forecast for the year.
